# Stockastic Analysis (Demo 4)


## Demonstration 4 Exercise 1

Let $(\Omega, \mathcal F, \mathbb P)$ be a probability space and $\mathcal M := \{A\in \mathcal F: \mathbb P(A)=0\}$. Why $\mathcal M$ not a $\sigma$-algebra? Describe the smallest one that contains all elements from $\mathcal M$.

<blockquote>
Obviously, $A^c = \Omega \setminus A \notin \mathcal M$, and thus it cannot be a $sigma$-algebra.

The smallest one is $\{A\in\mathcal F: \mathbb P(A)=0\}\bigcup \{A\in\mathcal F: \mathbb P(A)=1\}$
</blockquote>
